summary: This document is a chain of emails from March 17, 2020, between FBI and DOJ officials regarding a request from the Attorney General's office for the FBI to contact an individual named Ms. [Redacted], who claims to have information on the Epstein matter. The emails show coordination to initiate contact and report back.

persons.name: Ms. [Redacted]
persons.role: Individual with information on Epstein case
persons.context: An individual who has contacted the DOJ multiple times claiming to have information on the Epstein matter. The AG's office has requested the FBI contact her directly.

persons.name: Associate Deputy Attorney General & National Coordinator for Child Exploitation & Human Trafficking
persons.context: The sender of the initial request from the DOJ, asking the FBI to contact Ms. [Redacted] and confirm contact has been made.

connections.person2: Associate Deputy Attorney General & National Coordinator for Child Exploitation & Human Trafficking
connections.description: Ms. [Redacted] has contacted the DOJ, specifically the AG's office, with information on Epstein. The DOJ official is coordinating the FBI's contact with her.

events.title: DOJ Request for FBI Contact
events.description: The Attorney General's office requests the FBI contact Ms. [Redacted], who claims to have information on the Epstein matter, and confirm the contact.
personsInvolved: Associate Deputy Attorney General & National Coordinator for Child Exploitation & Human Trafficking

keyFacts: An individual, Ms. [Redacted], contacted the DOJ claiming to have information on the Epstein case, prompting a formal request from the AG's office to the FBI to contact her.
This was not the first time Ms. [Redacted] had reached out to DOJ leaders with purported information.
The DOJ official noted previous unsuccessful attempts to contact Ms. [Redacted] via email and phone.
The email chain shows inter-agency coordination (DOJ to FBI) regarding a potential witness in the Epstein investigation in March 2020.
